content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P1: M, 54, USW member, worked at Clairton coke works for 28 years, McKeesport, third-generation steelworker]
Q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.
"I'll be straight with you - things are tight. I make good money at the mill, $85K with overtime. But between the mortgage, the car payments, and everything costing more, it doesn't feel like I'm getting ahead. It feels like I'm running to stay in place."
participant_profile: M, 54, USW member, worked at Clairton coke works for 28 years, McKeesport, third-generation steelworker
section: Opening: Economic Reality in the Mon Valley
preceding_moderator_q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.
content_original: I'll be straight with you - things are tight. I make good money at the mill, $85K with overtime. But between the mortgage, the car payments, and everything costing more, it doesn't feel like I'm getting ahead. It feels like I'm running to stay in place.

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P2: F, 46, Hospital cafeteria worker, SEIU member, Wilkinsburg, single mom of two]
Q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.
"I'm a single mom. I work full time in a hospital cafeteria. I make $17 an hour. After rent and food and getting my kids to school, there's nothing left. My union fought for that $17 - it used to be $12. But $17 still isn't enough."
participant_profile: F, 46, Hospital cafeteria worker, SEIU member, Wilkinsburg, single mom of two

[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P3: M, 41, UPS driver, Teamsters, North Versailles, family man, politically disengaged until recently]

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P9: F, 44, Grocery store manager, UFCW, Irwin, worked through entire pandemic]
Q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.
"I managed a grocery store through the whole pandemic. We were "essential workers" but nobody treated us essential. We got sick, we kept working, and now they're cutting hours because profits are down. Where's the loyalty?"
participant_profile: F, 44, Grocery store manager, UFCW, Irwin, worked through entire pandemic

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P6: M, 35, Construction worker, Laborers union, McKees Rocks, first-generation college, changed careers]
Q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.
"Construction is actually doing okay right now. Infrastructure money is flowing. But the cost of living... man. I want to buy a house in McKees Rocks where I grew up, and I can't afford it. Houses that were $80K five years ago are $200K now."
participant_profile: M, 35, Construction worker, Laborers union, McKees Rocks, first-generation college, changed careers

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P5: M, 61, Retired Allegheny County employee, AFSCME, Homestead, pension very important]
Q: Thank you all for being here. Let's start with how things are going economically for your families right now.
"I'm retired, fixed income. The pension is good - thank God for the union - but inflation is eating away at it. I'm worried about Social Security. Every election Republicans talk about cutting it."
participant_profile: M, 61, Retired Allegheny County employee, AFSCME, Homestead, pension very important

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P1: M, 54, USW member, worked at Clairton coke works for 28 years, McKeesport, third-generation steelworker]
Q: What's driving these cost increases you're feeling?
"Everything. Gas was the killer this summer. I've got a truck - needed for the job - and it was costing me $100 to fill it. Groceries are insane. My wife says the same cart that used to be $150 is now $250."
participant_profile: M, 54, USW member, worked at Clairton coke works for 28 years, McKeesport, third-generation steelworker

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P7: F, 52, Nurse, UPMC (non-union), Penn Hills, frustrated with healthcare employer]
Q: What's driving these cost increases you're feeling?
"Healthcare costs. I work at UPMC - the biggest healthcare system in the region - and my own insurance is barely affordable. The deductible is $4,000. I'm a nurse making decent money and I put off going to the doctor because of the cost."
participant_profile: F, 52, Nurse, UPMC (non-union), Penn Hills, frustrated with healthcare employer

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P4: F, 38, Elementary school teacher, AFT member, Munhall, grew up in steel family]

"Teachers in Pennsylvania are actually paid okay compared to other states. But my husband was laid off during COVID and only found part-time work. We're a union household but we're still struggling."

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P8: M, 48, Bus driver, ATU, Pittsburgh city, lifelong Democrat but "not enthusiastic lately"]
Q: What's driving these cost increases you're feeling?
"Gas, groceries, and rent. The trifecta. I'm driving a bus, I see what the city looks like. There are homeless camps that weren't there five years ago. Something is broken."

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P10: M, 57, Electrician, IBEW, Braddock, union hall very active, political junkie]
Q: What's driving these cost increases you're feeling?
"The economy is complicated. Unemployment is low, jobs are available. But the jobs don't pay what they used to relative to costs. A union electrician job was middle class. Now it's barely middle class."

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P10: M, 57, Electrician, IBEW, Braddock, union hall very active, political junkie]
Q: You're all in union households. How does that shape how you vote?
"The union is my political education. Before I was in IBEW, I didn't think about politics much. Now I understand that every election affects my job, my pension, my healthcare."
participant_profile: M, 57, Electrician, IBEW, Braddock, union hall very active, political junkie

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P1: M, 54, USW member, worked at Clairton coke works for 28 years, McKeesport, third-generation steelworker]
Q: You're all in union households. How does that shape how you vote?
"USW endorsed Biden. I voted for Biden. But I know guys at the mill who didn't. Trump talked about bringing steel back and some of them believed him."

content:
[Pennsylvania Senate 2022 | Pittsburgh Area (Allegheny County - Monroeville) | P7: F, 52, Nurse, UPMC (non-union), Penn Hills, frustrated with healthcare employer]
Q: Let's talk about Tony Marchetti, the Democratic Senate candidate. What do you know about him?
"My father had hands like that too. He worked at J&L Steel for 38 years. Started right out of high school in '61. Back then you could walk out of South High and into the mill the same day. Good money, good benefits. He bought a house in Hazelwood, raised four kids. When the mills closed in the '80s it destroyed him. Took early retirement, but really he was just— I mean, the whole neighborhood emptied out. People lost their houses, their—"
participant_profile: F, 52, Nurse, UPMC (non-union), Penn Hills, frustrated with healthcare employer
